summary: This paper introduces CausalGF, a novel framework for cross-domain few-shot relation extraction using a Structural Causal Model (SCM). CausalGF demonstrates superior performance compared to baseline models. The authors have addressed some of the initial concerns regarding clarity and detail, but further improvements are needed regarding statistical significance, ethical considerations, and potential biases.

strengths.text: CausalGF achieves superior performance compared to baseline models in cross-domain few-shot classification on CrossRE and FewRel2.0 datasets. (Table 1, Table 2, Appendix D)
The paper introduces a novel causal perspective to address the cross-domain few-shot relation extraction problem, differentiating itself from conventional approaches. (Intro, Related Work)
The paper provides ablation studies to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. (Table 3, Table 4)
Figure 2 provides a clear overview of the CausalGF method, illustrating the key components and processes. (Fig 2)
The tables include accuracy percentages, which allow for direct comparison of the proposed method with baseline models. (Tables 1, 2, 5, 6, 8, 9)

weaknesses.text: The paper overclaims the generalizability of CausalGF, as the effectiveness is only examined on relation extraction tasks. (Sec 4)
The paper does not provide sufficient details on the specific causal effects being modeled, making it difficult to assess the validity of the causal claims. (Sec 3.2, Fig 3)

The paper lacks a detailed comparison with the most relevant prior work, especially those that also address cross-domain few-shot relation extraction, and the specific improvement over the closest baseline is not clearly articulated. (Related Work, Sec 4)
Figure 3 lacks clear axis labels and units, making it difficult to interpret the causal effects. (Fig 3)
The definition of 'C' in the SCM is unclear. (Sec 2.1)
The paper does not address privacy considerations, consent for data usage, or usage terms and ethical risks associated with the datasets. (Insufficient evidence)

The tables do not consistently report standard deviations or confidence intervals, making it difficult to assess the reliability of the results, and lack p-values to indicate statistical significance. (Tables 1-9)
The paper does not address potential biases in the data or model outputs, potential misuse cases, or the broader societal impacts of the research. (Insufficient evidence)

suggestions.text: Include a head-to-head comparison with a state-of-the-art method in cross-domain few-shot relation extraction, quantifying the performance difference. (Sec 4.1, Related Work)
Improve Figure 3 by adding axis labels and units to clarify the meaning of the causal effects and consider adding a legend. (Fig 3)

Expand on the 'causal operations' mentioned in the abstract and section 2.2, explaining how intervention, counterfactual generation, prompt generation, dynamic weighting, and loss function design are implemented. (Abstract, Sec 2.2)
Include a notation table to define all symbols used in the SCM and equations. (Sec 2.1, Fig 1)
Provide details on data collection, including consent procedures and privacy measures taken to protect any PII, and clearly state the terms of use for the datasets. (Appendix D)
Address the potential for bias in the datasets and how the model mitigates it. (Appendix D)
Include standard deviations or confidence intervals for all reported accuracy values and add p-values to indicate statistical significance of performance differences. (Tables 1-9)
Add a section discussing potential misuse cases and mitigation strategies. (Insufficient evidence)

Conduct an experiment comparing CausalGF with [1] Zeng et al. (2020) on the same cross-domain few-shot relation extraction task, using the same datasets and evaluation metrics. (Related Work, Sec 4.1)
Include a table or detailed discussion comparing the architecture, training objectives, and key components of CausalGF with [2] Yamada et al. (2020) and [3] Cong et al. (2021). (Related Work)
